yea it would suck to be in a coma

the mind is a trip

yea I love watching that stuff I'm the only one who's not a doctor in my family but I'm still in the medical field we used to have some real interesting dinner convos
What do you do in the medical field?
Surgical Technologist

Yea my job is to get all the instruments ready and basically be an extra pair of hands for the surgeon handing him all the instruments and helping him with the surgery. A good surgical tech knows the surgery just as well as the surgeon so he/she never has to ask for anything you should anticipate it
Yeah I here ya, probably makes the operation flow a lot smoother when the surgeon asks for a tool and you're not fumblefuckin around looking to find the blahblahmeter.
yea they get super pissed if you waste time each minute counts
what's the longest surgery you;ve ever taken part in?
8 hour spinal surgery
Yikes.  Well if Jose would've survived he probaby would have needed at least an 8 hour spinal surgery.

Sewing, vehicle maintenance, budgeting, childcare, basic home repairs, tax basics, etc.

I think its amazing how he turned his life around. A true inspiration
It's crazy how differently people react to similar circumstances. Thanks for chatting with me today. bye
Great talking to you. Goodbye
Hello. The situation in India is really terrible
Tell me about it. What a shame that the government of India isn't taking action. It's all about profit to them it seems.
Apparently. The most worrisome part of the situation is the fact that they barely compensate the victims
It's such a shame and a human rights abuse. Every living creature for that matter has a basic right to clean air and water. I couldn't imagine how bad it must be living near one of those mines.
Indeed. What do you think can be done on the part of the citizens in order to draw attention of the international communities?

Any change with government happens when people join together en mass. They need to be protesting outside of every politicians office. They should also spread this story to the international community to publicly shame their officials. Do you have any ideas of what can be done?
In all honesty, I have no idea.

I can think of how in the US change was created with the civil rights movement, and the women's movement when people stood together. I think that because people like us know about the story we can help by sharing this information on social media. We can be the media for them. But what can be done about the poor elephants? They have lost their homes because of the forest's being destroyed.
It's left for their government to decide

Ultimately yes. So it's up to everyone to make sure their government works in their best interest. Some people not even receiving compensation was terrible, but what about the kids who lost their lives? No amount of money can replace life.
True. It's really pathetic
There should be some sort of a program that helps these elephants get transported to a place where their homes won't be destroyed. Do you know of any charities that could help?
Nope. I doubt if the government will allow that.
You really don't think they would allow international help? I will pose the question... What would you do if this were happening in your hometown?
The government in India is corrupt. They are involved in the illegal trade of ivory. They won't allow any external body to interfere with their business
You make a really good point. I wasn't thinking about that.
I've read series of disturbing stories about their activities in the illegal trade of ivory
I've actually heard about that a while ago. Like I stated earlier... They care about profits over people.
Yeah. It's all about the rupees
I'm afraid that they will hurt these communities to the point where they create a refugee crisis.
That's the reality.
At the very least I wonder if we could donate things like breathing masks? Maybe that could help some to breath a bit better. Or if there is a way to get them clean water delivered.
That won't be a bad idea. How do "we" go about that
I would imagine that we could set up a GoFundMe campaign. That's definitely one way to go about it.
There have been several scam cases with GFM
There are alternative platforms. I would be happy to research them in detail. Charities can be looked into as well.
That'll be great
It's the least we can do, and like I said, posting on social media would help raise awareness. I just wish we could wave a wand and these communities would have clean air and water.
goodbye

i'm kind of running out of things to say, and we need at least 15 messages each that are relevant to the articles
yes...I think finding alternatives to coal is also a great idea
wind and solar are the first that come to mind
And nuclear sources..
are they capable to handle the necessary infrastructure for that? nobody wants a Chernobyl or Fukushima

they need better overall infrastructure. reaching a lot of these places is hard, if not impossible during some parts of the year

we are short a few still
good. I have few minutes left here. bye
bye
What did you think?
I can not blame them for wanting to industrialize, but it still horrible.
Yeah. I wish we had better options than coal. It seems like it's wrecking environments everywhere these days.
Yeah, the people and animals over there are suffering.
For sure. I can't imagine having an elephant burst through my house!
That would be very scary, then told you will get about 120 dollars for your broken leg.
Probably wouldn't even pay for a single night's stay in a hospital.
It sucks that the people who don't even work in the mines are getting such bad lung diseases.
Yeah. It's bad enough when things like this affect people actually involved, but when you have people getting hurt that weren't even part of it it's just so much worse.
I wonder if the animals are having lung issues too?
I wouldn't be surprised; many animals have similar lung structures as humans do. It's probably why the elephants etc. have been in so many altercations lately.
Like I said, can't get too mad because American used a lot of coal in the 1800s and early to mid 1900s.
Oh for sure. Many of the appalachian areas, for example, still have serious environmental damages and generational health issues.
Many of the same areas want to continue mining coals. It sucks that we live in a world where economics out weight health.
Yeah. Economics & tradition -- many families have been in the business for so long they can't imagine doing anything else. It's their way of life almost more than it is a living.
I know working in the US mine is a lot safer than the mine in India.
True true. Do you think we should be investing in finding cleaner forms of energy?
Yes 100 percent.
We're in agreement then. Something needs to be done soon before we run out of options & time.
I agree, but a lot people can not think about the future or other people besides themselves
"The tyranny of the immediate," as one of my professors once said.
I would like my children's children to be able to have a good life.
Same. Do you have any further thoughts?
No. Very nice chatting with you! bye
bye!
So I thought this was a really tragic and avoidable incident, what did you think
I was not really bothered, suicides are common
common?  I guess.  I don't really see it as an everyday occurence but anyhow
No not everyday but people do it and that is their choice
Yep, it is definitely their choice.  I still find it sad and very avoidable.  How sad for all their remaining family members.
I see what you mean but don't you think that being sad is just a waste of time?
Of course being sad is a waste of time, but it is still appropriate to feel sadness when you hear of a tragedy.  It's not like I'm dressed in black lighting candles and mourning, Jesus Christ.
Easy now. I did not mean it as a personal attack. It just doesn't make sense to me to be sad for someone who makes a conscious choice to end their own life. It's their choice
Well then be neutral towards it or happy, that's your right.  I find it sad anytime I hear about a tragedy that happens to others.  I am sad for their family who lost a beloved family member.
Let me be clear, I would rather no one commit suicide. How do we know that they were beloved? They could have despised each other
Sure they could have, but surely there was at least one person who appreciated this woman.  The article stated as much.
A fair point. When you think about it suicide is the easy way out. It is a bit cowardly. Choosing to continue living requires real courage

I agree suicide is extremely cowardly and suicide angers me.  It is a terrible choice for people to make and very selfish bc they are not considering how their actions affect others who are left behind.
We can agree on that. Do you know anyone personally who committed suicide?

Yes, and dealing with the fallout from it and the years and years of aftermath from that person's loved ones was terrible and very straining on everyone around.  The loved ones are STILL not healed and it has been 13 years
I got that impression from your responses. Do you think the loved ones deserve treatment or should preventative measures be the answer to suicide?

Can you clarify your question?  I am not sure I fully understand.  Do you mean grief counseling, or what preventative measures are you referring to?  Like should more have been done to try to help the person to start with?
Hospitalization, medication, psychotherapy, or even depriving someone of their freedom temporarily to ensure they do not take their life

I think those are reasonable steps to take in some cases but in others it might just make things worse.  I really don't know the answer to that.  If someone is that determined to take their own life it seems they will do it no matter what.  What do you think?  I don't think any of that stuff would have helped int he situation I'm referring to.  But who knows.
What do you think causes suicide? Most animals have such a strong will to live. What causes people to abandon or ignore that innate drive?

That's an interesting point about animals.  We don't see them giving up and killing themselves.  Fascinating question, I have no idea what it is about humans.  Maybe it has just become a part of our culture?  Like if the first animal did it then others would follow?  No clues.  What do you think

I am not sure myself. Most animals also do not have complex social structures and constructs like humans. I am sure that with those stark differences it would be good place to start the investigation.
Yes I wonder if it has ever been formally studied
I was wondering that myself. I think the best animals to study would be primates. I know chimpanzees can suffer from depression but I am not sure whether or not they commit suicide
OH yeah, really good point.  That would be very interesting to find out.  I guess it would be possible that they could because they do a lot of things that we do.
True, but they also don't do a lot of things we do and I am not sure whether or not suicide is in the Do or Don't category.
yeah exactly.  It is probably in the don't category.  I guess I could see them like refusing to eat or drink more than bringing a knife to their wrist.

Refusing food and sexual gratification are some of the things chimpanzees do when they are depressed. Similar symptoms in humans. If they were to commit suicide how do you think they would go about doing it?

I would think it would be passive, such as just refusing food and drink until they can't survive.  But maybe the urge to survive would override their depression?  Hard to say.  This has been an interesting conversation and I think we are at 15 messages so I will say goodbye for now and hope you have a great day
Yes very interesting. I hope you have a good day as well.
goodbye
bye
I found the article to be sad.
Me too, depression is a real issue.
It is and it is so difficult for people to seek help.
Yeah that is true, I think she wanted help but the system failed her.
Yeah, it did, I feel so bad for her family.
It made me think that money and frame does not matter when it comes to depression
Considering how many famous people seem to go through that, yeah it doesn't seem to matter.
I wonder if being famous adds more pressure and makes a person depressed?
I guess it could, especially if people have to put up a happy face for the public.
She should have never been left alone.
Yeah, but I think it is difficult to know what to do when someone you love is going through things that you don't understand.
That is true, but they knew she was having thoughts of killing herself.
Yeah, but maybe they thought that if they hovered too much, she would feel even worse, I don't know.
I guess that is why they have professionals. It is a hard subject.
It is something that people don't know much about especially considering how people ignored or locked away people who went through those things in the past.
I agree, most people see it was weakness and do not understand what is going on.
Yeah and they tend to shame people who seek help.
Or tell them how to deal with it.
Yeah, I don't know why that is. People have no problem seeking help when it comes to physical problems like a broken arm, but when it comes to mental problems forget about it.
I believe it comes down to people not wanting to be seen as weak. I do not think most people think about depression as chemicals in the brain.
I think that is better than it used to be.
Yes, there is a lot more awareness today.
Yes, and people are being more understanding about it.
Going back to what you said earlier. I feel bad for anybody family that has to go though this.
Yeah, it is has so be so hard for them.
It would be the questions about what should you have done.
Yeah, and it probably doesn't stop after somebody kills themselves. They probably still go through that their whole lives, what could they have done differently.
The internet makes it better and worst.
Oh yeah, so many hateful people who don't care who they hurt.
Well, hopeful everybody gets the help they need.
I hope so.
nice chatting with you.
same to you, goodbye

I always do that

Hello what did you think about the article?
It made me very sad.   She had such a hard life.   Whether it's socialized medicine or medicine here in the states, they miss so much with mental illness.
I agree. I feel like we are not doing enough about mental illness as a society
We aren't.   I am so tired of physicians sending you to a therapist to talk about your childhood or given medicine that doesn't work.   No one listens to the patient at all.
Exactly! It's very rare you find a good therapist. Most of them just can't wait to get home.

Yes!   I have suffered from dark depression my entire life.   It has nothing to do with your childhood.   You were wired that way at birth.   To date, physicians are just initially tapping how to help people.    Such a long way to go.
It must have been really tough for you. I think i have mild depression and it's such a struggle.

Oh it is.   Your family doesn't know how to help.   I just stay exhausted and really never socialize.   It really has nothing for therapists to address.   They can help victims of assault, etc. but they do not help for depression.   At least, that's been the case for me.    I'm sorry you suffer from it.
Yeah it's terrible. I have anxiety as well and everyday is a struggle to be honest
Just know I totally understand.   From personal experience, I think anxiety and depression go hand and hand.   I have a lot of anxiety around people or social settings.   What about you?
I am the same. I even have trouble going out with close friends sometimes. Just being around people, i don't like..

Yeah me too.   I looked at this article and remember this being in the news.   She did all the "right" things, physicians didn't share nor did they do anything with the statement of suicide.   That's unacceptable.
Yeah i still feel bad for the person in the article. Do you think people in society now are more accepting of mental illnesses?
No - they just look at you with that pitiful look and once employers know they look for ways to terminate you - if you had cancer everyone is supportive.
That's an interesting way to look at it but i agree. I honestly don't think society will EVER be accepting of people with mental illnesses. They'll always think of us as the "crazy" ones.
And your point is exactly why none of us want to convey we have it.   To your point, we are all crazy.
Well at least we all know deep down we're great people and just slightly different which makes us special.
We are - the thing we have to come to agreement on is how do we not feel like we can't do anything all the time.   I don't ever get a break from those feelings.

I get those feelings as well but i think we should tell ourselves that it's okay to have these feelings from time to time. But anyway, that's it for our convo, hope you have a great life and things improve! bye
It was nice chatting with you.    goodbye

This article just makes it so clear how little tolerance there really is in the world. It's sad we claim we are all so much more civilized these days, but the truth is we still seem people are more different than the same.
It is really sad
I find it interesting that so many people still use religion as an excuse for violence and only focus on the most violent parts of the religion and ignore the preachings of tolerance and peace.

I had never considered the zoo animals in countries like Venezuela. How sad.
Me, too. We think about the effects of poverty, war on humans ... but not animals.

That's an excellent point. The owners can't change the situation, that isn't fair at all. It isn't as if they want their animals to be sick/die!
I thought that embalming/preserving some of the animals was a valid idea, for science, but only if absolutely necessary and only if they were euthanized humanely.
Agreed - I would imagine that would provide a more humane death than starvation/malnutrition. Do you consider yourself to be an animal lover?
Definitely. Do you?
Absolutely. My grad degree is in Animal Behavior. :)  Do you have any pets?
That's interesting! I do; a dog and a cat.
Nice! Do they get along?
Yes, thankfully, haha. And the Great Dane that I babysit gets along relatively well, also.
That is a lot of dog to babysit! Is your dog a large breed, too?
He's 50-60 lbs, so mid-range? He's a catahoula.
I just googled Catahoulas - what gorgeous dogs! And I thought I knew my dog breeds. :)
I get a lot of funny looks when i mention his breed, sometimes! He is very handsome.
What's his temperament like?

Well, I adopted him at 3.5, so I can't testify what is breed standard and what was due to his previous owner/occupation. He was a military family's dog who "worked" on base, and he accompanied them to work. But he's wonderful. Very calm, emotionally sensitive. Great with kids. Not any of the agression or hyperactivity you hear about the breed.
Sounds wonderful - and sounds like you lucked out! Did you adopt him through a special service?

No, our local animal shelter, actually. The family was being relocated overseas and the base in the other location didn't allow dogs. They released him to the shelter so that his new home would be checked out and verified safe beforehand. We did luck out!

That's even better. I ask because I have friends who adopted a dog that was being trained as a mobility assistant - but he failed the final test after pulling someone out of a wheelchair to chase a rabbit. :)
hahah! those rabbits are tricky!
Right? And irresistable!
I'm surprised the dog got to the final test, but I guess it's a good thing a rabbit came by
LOL, seriously! That would have made for an unpleasant surprise for the new owner
could have been dangerous! but I'm sure he's a lovely pet
He was - they taught him to sort recycling (that's Seattle for you) and he was the ring bearer at their wedding
precious!
It was absurdly sweet
Do you have pets yourself? And did your degree focus on specific species?
I do - I'm not sure what happened, but I have cats ... 5 cats. It's a bit terrifying. And, yes, thanks for asking! I'm technically a "primatologist" - I ran around watching monkeys
interesting! I almost went into equine studies. instead I got my AKC training certificate and an elementary education degree lol
Nice! I work with some folks doing applied animal behavior with dogs. Cool stuff. And I teach at community college, so I'm right there with you! :)
I think we've hit our 15, but it was a fun chat with you!
Right back at you! Have a lovely day!

The child obviously stacked things inside the room to bring himself to window level and then pressed on the screen hard enough (this would take significant force on a properly installed screen) to fall through the window. Are you able to empathize with the people who are responsible for the spill and the subsequent clean up? Meaning, can you picture yourself being so concerned with money that you are effectively willing to destroy people's livelihoods?

I can understanding needing and wanting money and doing things you don't like to get it. But I can't imagine getting money in such a way that I'd hurt so many other people in the process and ruin an entire river. I can't imagine being that kind of person.

What would you consider an alternative to these destructive practices?

Well altneratives really depend on what type of mine it was. Basically for coal stop using fossils fuels. We have the ability to use wind, solar and water and we need to focus more on that. For minerals and gold and such, we need to figure out new manufacturing processes or start limiting the desire for those types of things so that mining isn't worth it.

Considering the fact that diamonds can now be convincingly replicated in laboratories, I can't see why the future might not unveil a sort of alchemical equivalent of changing abundant materials into formerly rare materials.

That would be a nice thought. It's going to take some major changes from everyone on earth to make a difference. I hope that we wake up to that and start now. It can't be done overnight and we need to start somewhere.

The pessimist in me often entertains the thought that we have passed a point of no return when it comes to our environment. I believe that a low energy future will be visited upon humanity by force, not by choice.

I am afraid that for a lot of things you might be right. I'd hope we could make the change because it's the right thing to do. However, I fear that for a lot of things it's going to come down to we have no other choice. Sad to think, but people don't often change unless forced to.

Change is scary. People are afraid of what they don't understand and that is why human society has had no long lasting fundamental shifts in centuries. Our only hope is that our past won't be forgotten once we get a chance to start over.

I'd like to hope that we'd learn from our mistakes, but it seems we only learn the lesson for so long and then we backslide. I think it's not even so much fearing the change as the fact that so many people fear for their money and industry that makes money now are things we need to move away from.
Do you feel that free market capitalism is a viable ideology moving forward?

I think it would be if it was a true free market system. But too often we say it's free market and yet we bail out companies because they are "too big to fail" but in a true free market if you fail you fail.

How do you feel about these, basically, Russian suicide communities?

I guess I think it's sad that kids feel so sad and alienated (or whatever) that they are drawn to them.  But I also think it's pitiful that people lose themselves in internet groups like this.  It's artificial.
Artificial? How do you mean?

I just think that the emotions we experience online are very different--much more intense--than what we experience in reality.  Ironically.  If we'd turn off our phones and the TV and went outside, we'd discover that there's a big difference between the virtual worlds on our screens, and the real world.  And the time we spend in the virtual ones doesn't seem to be good for our mental health, especially when we're already vulnerable.

It's true, a disturbing amount of humans put more effort into cultivating and maintaining a paltry digital simulacrum of themselves than they do their actual body/mind/relationships. I think in a lot of ways, for children growing up in our world, the digital world is much more real than the one that physically surrounds them everyday.

I agree, and I think that's sad.  It's ironic that in mental health, mindfulness is the current push.  And I think that the way we engage with the internet is the antithesis of being mindful.  So you have this strange dichotomy where more people need, or think they need, mental health help, which will push them towards things like mindfulness, while those same people do the exact opposite thing while engaging in their virtual worlds.

Mindfulness, in essence, is non-committal engagement of ones thoughts and feelings; acknowledging them as they are and letting them pass over you. The internet, on the other hand, is potentially a coliseum of unhinged emotional responses to both real world and subjective events and opinions. I think you're absolutely correct. People in our society are very quick to diagnose themselves, but rarely exert the effort to actually plumb the depths of their personal experience with a person who is qualified to make those diagnoses.
I'd suggest that in this story, the parents are most capable of providing help, in all ways, but apparently the parents are a large part of the problem, what with the drinking and abuse and whatnot.

I think they are the most capable and most incapable in the same turn depending on the circumstances. I think more actual community involvement is key in these types of situations. Less time online and more time interacting with human beings toward a common goal.

The statistics intrigued me.  First, the inordinately high depression and suicide rates for Russia.  But also the 5% number (teenage depression, I believe it was) for the rest of the West.  That number seems low to me, though I don't really know.
If factor in western countries with higher quality of life (Noway, Sweden, Denmark, Netherlands) whose suicide rates are less then 1% i'm sure it skews the data.
I'd also suggest that the FOCUS on the internet communities themselves is maybe misguided.  Seems like a whack-a-mole problem in terms of shutting them down.
It's much easier to make a half hearted effort to apply blame and deal with superficial corollaries of social problems than address them at the root.
Absolutely.  A culture of victimhood.  But it does nothing to help the actual kids.

No, meaningful action against this problem would require time, money, empathy and a sense of duty to ones fellow man that is very scarce in the world today. It's the equivalent of cutting hair and just expecting it not to grow back.

I also wonder what the right balance is for issues pertaining to mental illness and health.  At what point does "help" and "sympathy" becoming enabling and rationalizing?  When does trying to eliminate stigma becoming encouraging people to self-diagnose and use mental health as a crutch, or excuse.

Well, help and sympathy are two mutually exclusive concepts. A lot of the time people who are experiencing intense isolation just need someone to talk to. I think that people who are actually diagnosed rely too heavily on prescription medication (which are only supposed to be a temporary crutch) and prefer to ignore the human element in therapy which is often the most beneficial.

I'd agree with that.  In all parts of medicine, prescribing a pill has become the easy, satisfying thing to do. I'm flabbergasted when I see reports quoting the number of people taking things like Ambien.
Ambien, antibiotics, anti-depressants. It's a depressing and short sighted landscape to be sure. Thanks so much for chatting. I think you were probably the most insightful person so far. bye
Yes, nice chatting with you.  Have a nice day.  bye

Hey there.  I find it distressing anytime human technology is leading to the death of animals.  It seems so very frequent and common.  What did you think?
Yes, we certainly have a habit of encroaching on animals' habitats and doing harm to them.
Yes indeed we do.  It's really unfair to them but it's like an inevitable thing as society continues to grow.

Yes, there will always be compromises to be made.  Do we trade more greenhouse gasses for more dead birds, etc.  We're something of an invasive species and will continue to do what we do.  I think the question is just how, precisely, and what we choose to compromise.
Yes I agree.  It seems particularly sad when it is an endangered species that is being compromised.  I did not see anything in the article about what they planned to do to fix the situation, did you?

No, I didn't.  They were just talking about using this finding as further food-for-thought for wind farms.  I've also always wondered whether wind farms affect weather patterns.  You can't just take energy out of the air "for free."  That affects something.  I wonder if, like this bird situation, we truly understand the ramifications of these wind farms, and whether it's the right alternative energy to be pursuing so aggressively.
Yeah I agree with what you are saying completely.  It seems like in trying to fix things, there are often unintended consequences that further harm other things.
Yes, and we start down a path without being fully informed about what the ramifications are.  We did the same thing 100+ years ago with coal and oil!
Yeah totally!  And so many other things.  You would think we would have learned our lesson by now but nope.

Indeed.  I do wonder if there are specific things they can do to protect the birds, though.  Someone must be thinking of something.  Like, scents that deter them, or colors or something.  I don't know much about birds but you'd think there'd be some way to scare them or deter them from those locations.
Yeah that is a really good point.  You would think there would be something.  Surely scientists have vetted this out?

I would think so, but maybe it isn't a high priority or something.  I'm guessing the companies with a vested interest in wind farms don't want the bird killing to be paid attention to.  And maybe animal rights groups don't have the resources or something.  Not sure but I personally never hear that much about wind farms, positive or negative.  Energy talk tends to center around oil and coal.

Yeah I don't hear much about it either.  I don't really seek out that info though but I do read the news every day and I never see anything about it.  I have heard about the bird issue just over the years in different settings.  It seems to be an ongoing issue for sure.

I'd be interested to see how people felt if we just lay all the cards on the table.  Obviously we aren't this knowledgeable, but if we just said, "These are the pros and cons of wind, solar, oil, nuclear, etc. what do the people prefer?"  In other words, what do you sacrifice?  Dead birds, cost, nuclear fears, Carbon dioxide/global warming, etc.  I'd be interested to see how people chose because, again, you have to compromise somewhere.

Yeah totally.  It's easy for people to sit there and throw out idealistic notions but when it really came down to the practicality of it all and the pros and cons were laid out including cost, what would people choose

Right.  And I also feel like we, the people, don't get to have that much say.  This is a larger conversation than we have time for, but my energy costs have spiked dramatically in the last few years because the energy company is going towards wind, and it's expensive.  I'm not saying that isn't what I'd ultimately choose, but I don't even get a choice.  I have one utility company and have to accept their monopoly.
That is a good point as far as not getting any input.  Our costs have gone up too and we only have one company to choose from.

The other thing I'd be interested about is what rodent populations are like around these wind farms.  If you kill all the birds of prey, how does that affect these lands for farming or grazing.  You wonder if land owners, who've agreed to have these wind turbines erected on their lands, will regret it.

Oh yes true, ike the other populations will get out of control.  It could set the entire ecosystem out of balance.  Such is the danger when we tamper with nature.  Well I have enjoyed hearing your insights and hope you enjoy your day.  goodbye

I feel bad for the orangutans!  But this palm oil issue seems to be a very big one in Indonesia.
Yeah I feel bad for them too.  I don't know much about the whole palm oil issue, I found it a little confusing.
Yes, the article sure was.  But apparently Indonesia cuts down forests to grow palm trees to make palm oil.  But the palm oil industry is apparently terrible for the environment in all sorts of ways.
The whole deforestation thing sounds damaging to me in and of itself.  It seems we should b e protecting forests, not destroying them.
Right, particularly when what they're doing apparently violates an international agreement they're apparently part of.  But it's about economics, so that usually wins out.
Yes, that too.  It seems so damaging on many levels.  I guess their country is pretty impoverished though and this is one of their main economic resources?

Yes.  So you have the age-old question of what are the rights of mankind and what are the rights of nature?  But also, what is best for mankind's present versus the future?  There's always a compromise, and we usually choose us, and now.
Yeah totally.  I mean I try to put myself in the shoes of people that live there and perhaps that is their only means.  I really don't know enough about Indonesia to say.
Yeah, me too.   These are complicated issues.  There isn't some simple, perfect answer or we'd likely have found it.
Yeah exactly.  I'd like to think they are doing the best they can and trying to ensure their people survive.  I don't know.

But I do think it underscores one challenge we have in these global issues.  Different countries/cultures/economies see the world very differently.  In the west, in our relative prosperity, we focus on certain things.  And in these high-population, low-wealth countries, they focus on much more basic goals.  Sort of like a Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs thing.  The point is, getting everyone to go along with some worldwide issue like reducing greenhouse gases, is extremely difficult if not impossible.
Yeah I agree.  It's like we are on different pages.  So we need to be able to take their perspective before we judge I Guess.
For sure.  I was also wondering about orangutan populations and how bad they actually are.  Not sure where else they live, or if there are healthier populations elsewhere.

Yeah I really know practically nothing about them.  The estimate of how many were dying was really vague, like a very wide range.  I reckon it is hard for them to even know exactly the impact they are having.

That's the other thing with all these issues.  I admit I'm ignorant, but I'm also not sure if I can even trust information and data we get, or for sources to really represent the whole picture.  Everything is so political and narrow.  And we're just bombarded with so many issues and opinions these days.  At some point you just throw up your hands and say, I'm not sure what to think.
Yeah totally, that is so very true.  And everyone has a bias or a political agenda they are trying to promote, and you can distort facts to sway things a certain way with almost anything.

That's the thing about the internet.  I think people feel they're MORE informed these days, but I'm not sure it's the opposite.  There's just too much information.  I don't think our brains are designed to handle so much.  We can make sense of what we can touch (figuratively) but trying to comprehend this incomprehensibly large planet?  I think it's too much.
Yeah exactly!  And we all have our biases and seek out information that confirms the things we believe and ignore other info.
Yes, I admit that I'm as guilty as anyone.  I cherry pick opinions and stories that corroborate my beliefs.

This is certainly a contentious issue.

It is very much. I am afraid we're going to keep seeing it. However, I feel we are only getting half the story and we're only making national headlines about cops shooting people and not people shooting cops.

Yes, I like to say that just because a story is true, doesn't make it representative of the country as a whole.  If the news decided to run stories about kidnappings, they could very easily have the country go into a panic over that.  We get just the slightest sliver of a glimpse of the country through the news, and it skews our perspective.

I totally agree. We tend to see the media picking and choosing what they focus on. We don't even get a fair representation of happenings. Instead, we get a skewed view to press a political hot button and not giving a fair understanding of the incidents.

Right.  A narrative gets created and information either adds to it or gets disregarded.  For example, blacks are actually killed less often by police than whites based on encounter rates, but that piece of data has no place in politically-charged inflammatory subjects like this one.  Only emotions and strawmen do.

I couldn't agree more. Just like more blacks kill one another than are shot by cops, but we make it out as if the only people killing black people are cops. I wish we would get a better representation of facts in the media to educate people. That was how media was supposed to work. These days it seems more like they simply want to grab headlines and push political agendas.

Yeah, I think it's pretty sad.  The other thing I say to people is to use their own experiences to guide their beliefs more than stuff they see on screens.  How many hundreds of thousands of POSITIVE, PRODUCTIVE, LEGAL, and APPROPRIATE police encounters occur each day for every one that goes horribly wrong?  Again, a cop might shoot and murder an innocent civilian, but that's not our reality.  The event might be the truth.  But it's not representative of the true state of the nation and what the vast, vast, vast majority of people experience in their lives instead of on screens.

I couldn't have said it better myself. We tend to take the extreme cases that make the headlines and make that the normal reality when it is far from the truth. I just recently saw a video of a black man with a knife. He was ordered to drop it and continued to advance on the cop. The man was shot several times, went down and then jumped back up. He attacked a second officer before he was finally taken down. That video didn't make headlines to show how often cops have little choice but to defend themselves.

Yeah, precisely.  I also ask myself in these issues, how much danger do we expect these cops to put themselves in?  How close to certain death do we expect them to come before they're allowed to defend themselves?  I'm sorry but it's not hard to get a cop not to abuse you: do what he says.  They don't have any more desire to get violent than you do.

I've said the same thing many times myself. I've had interactions with cops and never had any violence or threat of violence. If an officer asks you to do something, do it! That's what I was taught growing up. Respect authority figures. Instead, today everyone thinks they don't have to listen to anyone. They don't respect authority. They want to live stream it and get reactions on social media.

Yes, that's the question I want answered.  It's not, "Why are people getting shot by police?"  It's, "Why is there a generation of people, and apparently predominantly blacks, who don't think they have to respect the law and law enforcement?"

I'm afraid it's what they are being taught by parents, social media and even music. They are told people are, "out to get them" and so they don't have to listen to anyone -- not just cops, but teachers and anyone in authority. It's a sad state of affairs I'm afraid.

Yes, I think that teachers and principals have largely abdicated their authority and influence.  Heck, even parents, who often seem more intent on being friends than authority figures to their children.

Well we don't enforce any rules on children anymore. We don't punish them. We give them time outs, as if that will teach them anything. I got spanked a few times growing up and I learned how to behave. Yes, some children were abused, but the majority of parents used spanking properly and taught children how to behave. Now, kids threaten to call CPS on parents if they don't get their way.

Yes, I think it's sad an ironic.  I often wonder how a generation of people who were spanked but couldn't possibly believe they were abused, could go on to think spanking is so wrong.  I have a theory but it'd take too long to discuss here.  Just a weird irony, in my opinion.

It is. It's like everything in society now, though. We have gone to the extreme to avoid upsetting anyone or offending anyone. Doesn't anymore remember the old saying, "You can't please all of the people, all of the time!" Suddenly, everyone thinks they get to always have their way no matter what because otherwise, I'm offended!

Yeah, it's just crazy.  Even the people who believe that's how it should be can't help offending people.  There's always someone who's going to be offended.  We should be teaching people to be responsible and resilient, not to see themselves as victims.

It's back to that everyone get's a trophy theory. We suddenly can't disappoint anyone. Life is full of disappointment. We can't always have our own way. We're supposed to live by the majority rules theory. However, even in politics we see people forget that. Instead, don't like the president, then refuse to accept him. It's crazy. I've voted for plenty of people that didn't win elections but still respected those that did.

Absolutely.  And the ultimate irony is that by trying to make everyone's life struggle-free, we increase their struggles by making everyone less capable of dealing with them.  We know it's unhealthy and unproductive to treat kids like this, make them soft and feeble.  It's not just silly, it's actually detrimental to the people we're trying to protect.

Exactly! Instead of letting them learn when they're young and the disappointments are more minor that they can survive not always getting what they want. We let them grow up thinking everything should go their way. Then suddenly, they don't get into the college they want or get the job they want and they can't deal with it.
Yeah, it's a bizarre tack we've taken and I wonder when it or if we'll change course.  Anyway, it was great talking with you.  I really enjoyed it.  Hope you have a great day.  bye
Was great chatting with you as well. Enjoy your day. goodbye

The government has long stopped working in the interest of the common man.

Climate change or an asteroid.
Yes, something at that level. People won't change unless their comfort is threatened. It doesn't have to be existential, but big enough to rattle everyone.
Do you think police should be enforcing laws dealing with what an adult does with their own body?

Well, I think there are way too many laws governing personal behavior. Most things that do not directly harm others should be legal. Abortion. Suicide. Gambling. Prostitution. Some drugs. Legalize, regulate and tax. The problem isn't the act themselves, it's the criminality, which breeds abuse and exploitation, because where can you turn if you know that what you're doing could get you locked up?

I see them speeding up.
It's definitely a possibility. With the coming recession tensions are only going to run higher.

I agree. It was nice chatting with you! bye
Back at you. bye
I found this article obnoxious.  What were your thoughts on it?
Obnoxious in what sense?
It attempted to blame an increase in hate crimes (which it later retracted, saying they were likely at the same level as they were in 2015) on Trump.

Yeah, but the media's pretty good at that, aren't they?  I don't think Trump creates anger and hatred.  He might embolden it.  Maybe.  But it already exists and is a function of our society, not one man.

Those are my exact sentiments.  It is a mindset that has entered society and is probably exacerbated by social media and the rapid exchange of information, ideas, hatred, and anger that is prevalent in society today.  To blame it on Trump, one person, is just absurd.

I also sympathize fully with people who are furious after terrorist attacks.  I personally wouldn't go harass or assault an innocent person because of it, but I understand the feelings behind it, even if I don't condone the behavior.

Yes, and there have been a large number of terrorist incidents that were perpetrated by Muslims.  So to me, that would explain why people are targeting Muslims in retaliation.  Which is not right at all, but it is the explanation for why that is happening.

I guess I also feel that the notion of everyone living together peacefully and harmoniously is misguided.  There will always be winners and losers, always be some sort of "us versus them."  You see it in gender issues, race issues, political issues.  I think certain majority elements in our society are waking up to this and pushing back.  And I don't blame them.

You make a good point.  That is probably an idealistic notion that is not grounded in reality.  I do wish people would learn to live and let live a little bit more.  Just mind their own business and enjoy their lives.

Yes, I don't want to present too cynical and callous a view.  People can form stable societies.  But our current one likes to highlight differences and perceived inequalities, and that feeds a very antagonistic culture.  I think we know too much about each other, see too much that other people have that we don't, and it creates unrealistic expectations about how the world can possibly work.  We don't all get to have what we want.  Few, or none, do

Yes and social media probably feeds into that.  Not to keep blaming social media for all our problems because I certainly don't think that's the case, but I Do think it heightens the issue you are describing.  People see differences and inequalities and just have much more information than they did in the past.

Yeah, don't feel bad about ripping on social media.  I think it's a real problem.  Or, as you say, it heightens all these problems.  I think it's a real problem and will be interested to see how things unfold going forward, whether people start turning away from it or they double down and more of our lives gets filtered through our screens.  The problem is it's addictive for people, among other things, and I think that makes it harder for people to decide not to use it, even when they know it makes them unhappy.

Yeah it definitely becomes compulsive for people, like an integrated and critical part of their lives almost.  Something did not really happen unless it's documented on social media.  Kinda crazy to me, but whatever.  Either way, I do think it is intensifying a lot of these problems and it will definitely be interesting to see what happens over the next century.

Yeah, I thought about that once.  Think about how much our minds now associated "importance" with seeing it on a screen.  We've been conditioned to think that way.  And I think it works the other way, too.  When we see something, we make it important by recording it.  A strange phenomenon, that something isn't important until it's digitized.

It is a very strange phenomenon.  And it has happened so fast.  It's crazy to think when I was a kid the only phones we had were in the house, and the computer was basically just a very simple word processor.  My kids can't even fathom it.  We used a phone book to look up a phone number.
Yeah, I was the same.  I don't even have a cell phone myself.  I'm annoyed that so few people are now in the phone book.  Some places apparently don't even have phone books anymore.

Yeah I don't even know where I would get a phone book.  They don't distribute them where I live.  I have a cell phone but it stays off on a shelf unless I leave the house.  It is for emergency use when I am out.
Yeah, I don't ever judge people for having a cell phone.  I just joke that "I'm not that important," which has more meaning than I let on, but I mostly mean as a joke.

LOL apparently I am not either.  But I am perfectly fine with that.  This is how I choose to live my life.  Well it has been a pleasure speaking with you, thank you for sharing your insights with me.  I hope you enjoy the rest of your day, goodbye
For sure, great chatting with you.  I enjoyed it and appreciate your perspective.  Have a great day.  bye

Reading about that situation with the poachers was pretty upsetting. To think that the changes being made to ensure poaching ends and they are being stopped by local governments is just upsetting.
Yes, although I'm not sure it was local governments, just local villagers.  Still, that must have been a horribly frightening experience.

Yeah that could be possible, and so terrifying to just be doing your job and being attacked like that. I wonder if this is the right way to stop poaching, or if there was a better way than having people just have to grab poachers in towns like that.

Yes, I'm not sure.  The whole article was a little sparse on details, which I would have appreciated.  It didn't explicitly say what the villagers were angry about, although one could guess.  And I also wondered who called for the helicopter.  Seems unlikely the rangers would have survived that scenario, but who knows.

Yeah it definetely felt like the article just wanted you to just to the conclusions on your own. I'm guessing the poachers were members of the community and that caused the mob. I wonder how the poahcer even got away from them in the first place.

Yes, the fact that he escaped seemed incompetent, unfortunately.  But of course that's a large part of the story.  There aren't enough resources or competence to properly deal with the issue.  And there's probably corruption, too.

Yeah for sure as easy as it seems there is so much ground for them to cover and animals to protect. If only they had more resources or there was a way to stop black market trade so poachers are not incentivized to hunt these animals.

Yes, I think that's one of the tacks governments are taking is to focus on the demand.  Not sure how well it's worked but they're definitely putting pressure on things like ivory demand, maybe similar to same way that there's sort of a backlash against blood diamonds.  I was curious what animals were being poached in this story.  I don't believe it said, did it?

No i don't think there was a mention of it. They only mentioned the country and the continent so the first thing my mind jumped to was to african elephants which i think are still endangered. I definitely think that there is progress being made on poaching and hope stories like this are not commen.

Yes, I think it's particularly disheartening when the story is of the authorities losing the battle.  I guess I feel like if nothing is currently being done to stop it, then there's the distinct possibility that change can and will happen.  But if they're already trying and failing, then it feels less likely to me that things can improve.

Yeah for sure, it seems like we never really hear articles that are good news or updates on constant issues. Or maybe that is that people know that those articles would not cause as much noise so there is less interest in talking about them.

Yes, I certainly think that's part of it.  I'm curious what will happen to the people in the village?  The article is concerned about the cowardly police officers, and I get that.  But will there be any charges brought to the villagers for nearly killing the rangers?  I'd like to know that.

I don't think there is any good way to deal with the villagers, if it was a mob of people that attacked them then what do you do arrest them all? I think at best the rangers just now no they must be careful with that village.

Yes, that's a good point.  Unfortunately, I think it only serves to embolden and legitimize their actions.  If there are no repercussions for waging "war" on anti-poaching, then how can the anti-poaching side ever have any real authority and success?

Definetely it sends the message that if you want to poach then just make sure that the nearest village is benefiting from it and you wont need to worry. Maybe the government sends people to the villages to work as police or peacekeepers of some sort but that could just make tensions worse.

Yeah, if nothing else I'd certainly be nervous to be the guy sent there, seeing how they treated these rangers.  I feel like you'd probably have to convince people associated with poaching that there's an economically viable alternative to their poaching.  The problem is that I'm not sure what that is in Mozambique.

Yeah me either, it seems like all these people see is the money lost from not poaching. It feels bad but maybe there should be incentives for villages if the population of poached animals gets above a certain point?

Yes, that's certainly an idea.  I think it's just human nature.  It's Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs. What'd you think of the article?
I had mixed emotions, I guess.  How about you?
My emotions could also be considered "mixed."

I guess I'm not all that averse to the notion of limiting children's exposure to second-hand smoke through regulations.  But the explanation for why these people wanted to do it seemed bizarre.  To prevent children from seeing people smoke... I don't agree with that.
As a smoker myself, I felt the need to parley with the author of the article.

How do you feel about the dwindling space and opportunity you have to smoke?  Do you think you should be allowed to smoke anywhere?  I think it's certainly a mixed message we send about smoking.  It's legal.... only we don't want you to do it anywhere.

Frankly, I enjoy the fact that the space is dwindling. Smoking is more than a nicotine fix for me. It also gives me an excuse and an opportunity to get away from other people for a while. The only time it really bothers me is when I've got a flight with connections.
And how about from a more political perspective?  Do you think towns, for example, should have the right to basically tell you you can't smoke anywhere in public?
The government dictates a lot of what people can and can't do in public. I'm assuming you don't smoke. Are you bothered by seeing/smelling people smoke in public?

It depends.  That's kind of the point I'm getting to.  You can find precedent to justify banning smoking in public.  You can find precedent to not.  I was just curious what your take is as a smoker.  i'm not a smoker, but in most situations I'm not averse to the idea of people being allowed to smoke.

It may not be an apt analogy, but I equate smoking in public to open carry. I'm not comfortable with seeing a person holding a gun on their hip, it makes me nervous for my health and the health of those around me. But, people are allowed to do it and I just keep my distance.

Yeah, I can understand that.  I'm sure that part of my attitude towards smoking is from experience.  I grew up with people smoking in public and around me, so it was never strange.  But people who grew up more recently view it very differently.  Think about how crazy it is to think that, not so insanely long ago, people could smoke on a plane.  It seems like another planet.
Planes, schools, hospitals... I'm trying to think of another behavior that has been similarly restricted but i'm coming up short.

Yeah, in my lifetime I can't think of any.  When was public drinking outlawed?  That was probably legal at one time.  Times do change.  Drinking and driving wasn't always illegal.  And one of my family's first cars didn't have seatbelts.  And that was legal.
My grandfather had a '57 Chevy that didn't have seatbelts. You can still have open containers in Missouri. Our childhood hasn't disappeared yet.
I wouldn't mind seeing some restrictions on cell phone use.  Civility would spike dramatically if people had to look at real people more often, I think.
That's actually an idea everyone could profit from. Imagine having to look service workers in the face and appreciate their contribution to society at large.
Yeah, it's interesting how as a society we're up in arms about one addiction (smoking) while disregarding another one.
Eh, more people profit from cell phone use than smoking. It's been a joy chatting with you. Have a good one! bye
Yeah, nice chatting with you.  Have a good day.  bye
